text: Signals transduced through the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecule on T lymphocytes activate NF-kappa B .
We have demonstrated that native envelope glycoproteins of HIV-1 , <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can induce activation of the transcription factor , NF-kappa B .

The stimulatory effects of <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are mediated through the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecule , since pretreatment with soluble <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> abrogates its activity .

The <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappa B complex consists of <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> c-rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins .

text: The stimulatory effect of <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on NF-kappa B activation is protein synthesis independent , is dependent upon protein tyrosine phosphorylation , and abrogated by inhibitors of protein kinase C .

The <extra_id_0> gp160 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated activation of NF-kappa B in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> positive T cells may be involved in biological effects , e.g . , enhanced HIV replication , hypergammaglobulinemia , increased cytokine secretion , hypercellularity in bone marrow and apoptosis .
